div.p:
It was but a few days ago dear Mrs Brinkley
that I was reading over your beautiful and touching
letter on the death of your beautiful and young
daughter in law daughter-in-law
- little thinking that in two
short weeks I was to call on your feelings again
and open the scarcely closed wounds of your
sorrowing heart by telling you that we have lost
our dear William - our dear son I might say with
truth - for though neither you nor I brought him
in to the world he loved & treated us as if we had
been his real mothers - During this fatal illness
his thoughts often recurred to the time when he
was so ill at the observatory when you and the
Bishop and every one were so kind to him
and often said "dear Mrs Brinkley my dear other
"mother - do write to her and tell her how ill
"I am and how tenderly and how gratefully I
"think of her" - I did not write because I
still hoped that in a few days I might tell
you of your his illness as of a thing that was past

and only call upon you to rejoice with me
at his convalescence.

The disease was inflammation of the Lungs -
and had I fear taken too fast hold of him
before he returned home for medical art
to save him - The skilful skillful surgeon near us
and a physician from Dublin had a bad opinion
of him from the first - they agreed in ordering
repeated bleedings which relieved the cough & pain
but never touched the pulse; it continued from
first to last above a 100 generally 120 -
At first blisters on the chest could not be made
to rise - or even to produce a prickly feeling &
at last when they did rise - the discharge
produced no relief. Yet for two days (monday
& tuesday last) he seemed to mend - and even
on wednesday morning his pulse was a little bett
but that day some most fatal change took place
between my first and second visit to him, which
so altered his looks that I was shocked when
I saw him and from that moment he declined
so rapidly - that no hope could be recalled

twelve hours! I have allowed my pen to run
on more at length to you my dear Mrs Brinkley
than to any one else to whom I have written
for he wished that you and the dear Bishop
should know as much about him as possible
and I know so much of your kind natures
that you will feel sympathy with all of us
for the irreparable loss we have sustained
and forgive me for renewing your own
sorrow by describing ours.

I think that the all wise disposer of events
will strengthen our bodies - and teach our
minds to receive benefit from this severe
lesson - by preparing each of us for our latter
end and increasing the faith that is in us
that may be worthy servants of Christ and
keep us from murmuring at the decrees of God.
William died at half past 4 on thursday morning the
7th.! and the grave will soon contain all that
once was him.

How closely are life and death brought together! -
On the 5th at 3 oclock o'clock my dear Sophy gave me another
Grandaughter granddaughter - born 14 days before her time - but
both mother and child were doing well when Harriet Butler
who was fortunately with her - wrote to me -
I perceive that I have omitted to mention - that dear
William's head remained perfectly clear - and
though he had so much fever had no tendency
to delirium - but one day - & then only slightly

Dear fellow - he knew us all to the last moment
wished so much that his brother Francis had been
with him - begged I would not leave him &
died while I held his dear cold hand -
It still appears a frightful dream to me, and
I can hardly persuade myself that I shall never
again hear that affectionate voice; or see those
eyes look upon me again. To me he was a most
kind son - a living image of his dear father in
many ways - and most particularly in an
uncompromising honesty and independence
of character which rested on its own integrity;
and also in the incomparable fertility of his inven
-tive inventive powers - which continued to the last
and alas, contributed to their own destruction
for it was not possible to enforce the tranquility
that was so necessary. It was not possible to
keep him from inventing, speaking, directing.
How do I now regret the mistaken tenderness
that permitted those exertions - or rather that
I made so unwise a calculation when I thought
the opposing of these exertions would fret & hurry him

him more than the letting him get them off
his mind! - Perhaps the end would have been
equally fatal - and he would have been less
comfortable - As it was he frequently said
he felt perfectly happy - that the delight of
being at home surrounded with kind and
sympathising sympathizing friends gave him a degree of com
-fort comfort he had been a stranger to for many months -
That he could not call to mind the having willingly
done harm to any human creature - That he
could not reproach himself with having seduced
or corrupted or blasted the fair fame of any female
whatever - That he had not lived in the practice
of any sin - and that the sufferings and trials of
this life of which he had borne many, were wisely
ordained by providence both as trials of what we
could bear - and as means of weaning us from
the love of this world.

Yet when he said his he had not a thought that
his latter end was so near - Recovery - and the
hope of spending the next winter at Naples were
